abstract_summ: The SARS coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic is a global challenge, which the scientific community has tackled by mounting extensive global collaborations, combining expertise in diverse areas and applying cutting-edge techniques, to dissect mechanisms underlying coronavirus disease-19 (COVID-19) pathology.This article provides a May 2020 snapshot from Professor Paul Young, who is part of a group working with urgency on Australia’s leading COVID-19 candidate vaccine.The strong infectiousness of SARS-CoV-2 forces medical personnel to do good and needful safeguard against virus.• The world is working with unprecedented fervor and spending billions of dollars to find a vaccine for COVID-19.The current coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic is rapidly spreading around the world.On the 26th February 2020, a meeting was held at the Royal Society of Medicine between key advisers in UK healthcare and law enforcement to discuss quarantine measures in response to the current COVID‐19 outbreak.
title_summ: Visualizing an unseen enemy; mobilizing structural biology to counter COVID-19The network effect: studying COVID-19 pathology with the Human Cell AtlasCOVID-19 Reinfection: Myth or Truth?The COVID-19 Pandemic from an Ophthalmologist’s PerspectiveDisease X ver1.0: COVID-19Covid‐19: countermeasure for N95 mask‐induced pressure soreHuman papillomavirus:Coronavirus: reducing the impact of quarantineWhatsApp messenger as a teledermatology tool during coronavirus disease (COVID-19): From Bedside to Phone-side.Serology for SARS-CoV-2: Apprehensions, opportunities, and the path forward.The other invisible enemy
